author: Petermarcu
body:
@RussKeldorph commented on [Mon Jul 30 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1828)

_From @ygoe on June 30, 2018 14:13_

While there is a working binary download for dotnet (.NET Core) for ARM32 that works on a Raspberry Pi B 3+ with a current Raspbian OS, there are no instructions how to install it. And there are no packages for the OS, too. So it's a bit of a mystery how to actually make .NET Core work on a Raspi.

I think there should be a package for that OS. It should be as simple as that:

    sudo apt install dotnet

Maybe a custom package source needs to be added, but definitely no manual tar file works. Mono was easier to install when it was current like 5 years ago.

Since the docker support on the Raspi with dotnet-runtime packages is very poor (multi-arch fails, need to select arm32 image specifically, can't get my app in a custom image), I need to install .NET Core on the Raspi OS itself.

_Copied from original issue: dotnet/coreclr#18732_

---

@RussKeldorph commented on [Mon Jul 30 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1828#issuecomment-409057915)

_From @ghost on June 30, 2018 16:45_

Current blocker for ARM32 in general is https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/8998. In my understanding it's about couple of lines of XML changes in dotnet/cli to pack the right binaries (like done for ARM64 https://github.com/dotnet/cli/pull/9011/files) and then testing cross build on x64 (which is a more involved task).
That said, CoreCLR/CoreFx/CoreSetup parts for ARM32 are done.

---

@RussKeldorph commented on [Mon Jul 30 2018](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/1828#issuecomment-409058152)

@Petermarcu Wasn't sure how big the gap is or where this request should be tracked.  Sorry if this is already covered somewhere else.

author: leecow
body:
SLES returns the following when installing:

```
The following 6 packages are going to be upgraded:
  aspnetcore-runtime-2.1 dotnet-host dotnet-hostfxr-2.1 dotnet-runtime-2.1 dotnet-runtime-deps-2.1 dotnet-sdk-2.1

The following 6 packages have no support information from their vendor:
  aspnetcore-runtime-2.1 dotnet-host dotnet-hostfxr-2.1 dotnet-runtime-2.1 dotnet-runtime-deps-2.1 dotnet-sdk-2.1

6 packages to upgrade.
Overall download size: 167.1 MiB. Already cached: 0 B. After the operation, 365.3 KiB will be freed.
```

Appropriate content should be added to packages to satisfy the support information check.

nodes.author: rakeshsinghranchi
nodes.body:
Here are the findings:
-	Issue is specific to SLES package without or with unknown support status ( L1,L2,L3,Additional customer contract Necessary ) report this issue. Support level details can be found at http://support.novell.com/products/linuxpointofservice/supported_packages/ .
-	Information about support status is not in rpm header. The information may be shipped in SUSE specific extension file named susedata.xml. If it’s not available , the package reports this message to inform system admins. 
-	To fix this issue, primary.xml file need to be updated with rpm repository Primary data xml file.

https://en.opensuse.org/openSUSE:Standards_Rpm_Metadata#SUSE_specific_data_to_be_appended_to_primary.xml_data_.28packages.29

author: ruimaciel
body:
In order for linux users to evaluate the new 2.2-preview3 release of the dotnet sdk, it would be nice if the new releases were made available through official DEB packages.

Furthermore, Ubuntu and Debian enable users to pick which version of a software package is currently available by default by registering them with the update-alternatives command.  In order to be able to run multiple versions of the dotnet SDK in the same machine (say, for instance, 2.1 and 2.2-preview3, and in the future also 2.2 and 3.0) it would be nice if the official installer registered each package with the update-alternatives and stored them in a directory structure that enabled users to keep multiple versions installed.

Run dotnet commands

Dotnet core 2.1 runtime installations depends on debian packages. If I want to install dotnet core 2.1 runtime in a python alpine base image, it seems like not possible today?

Any suggestions appreciated to install dotnet core 2.1 in python alpine base image. (NOT looking to get a dotnet core 2.1 base image alpine and installing python on it - this exists)

author: leecow

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
First, to make sure everyone's on the same page, the way this works right now is that the macOS .NET Core installer creates a file `/etc/paths.d/dotnet` that contains the install location. This allows the macOS tool `path_helper` to find it while spawning a new shell:

https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/e550056ab91de0b5c6b82518a99dab7ccc801f83/src/pkg/packaging/osx/sharedhost/scripts/postinstall#L9-L17

(This doesn't appear to assume `bash` to me, but I wasn't able to find any useful info about how `tcsh` in particular interacts with `path_helper` when I poked around.)

I traced this down to this PR: https://github.com/dotnet/cli/pull/840. Apparently we switched from symlinks to `path_helper` to work around a bug, not any reason I'd call significant. 😕

`path_helper` is apparently a controversial utility based on what I'm finding on the internet. At face value, making a symlink seems simpler and probably more normal, perhaps especially when comparing it against the Linux ecosystem.

---

There's precedent, though, of other similar products using `path_helper`:

The Mono installer uses it at the moment: [postinstall#L24-L34](https://github.com/mono/mono/blob/c5b88ec4f323f2bdb7c7d0a595ece28dae66579c/packaging/MacSDK/packaging/resources/postinstall#L24-L34). The switch from symlinks to `path_helper` seems to have happened unfortunately without any description here: https://github.com/mono/bockbuild/commit/3e900296aa8eb7ef91fd6cf0b1b6f540c6242d74#diff-d4ed8cbf31db07014a6866e74f3f568b

Go also apparently currently uses `path_helper`: https://stackoverflow.com/q/38337790. There's also a brief justification for using it in general:

> because automatic software installation (and what's more important UNinstallation) is much easier this way. Many Linux distros switch to .d directories for many configuration files (Apache 2.0 was AFAIK the first program to support this kind of stuff) because it makes administration much easier.

---

It seems like we *should* be able to depend on `path_helper`. I fully admit I most likely don't understand the tradeoffs we're making, though.

@leecow do you know who's working on Mono macOS packaging who could weigh in? (Or another macOS installer expert?)

/cc @dleeapho

nodes.author: grosch
nodes.body:
LOL!  Go and Mono, both super niche tools.  Look at something like Homebrew, specifically designed for the mac, which installs hundreds (thousands?) of packages properly.  It always uses symlinks.

If you're really going to look at changing your installer, I'd ask you also look into why you're writing to /usr/local/share in the first place and even worse putting a binary at the same level as files and directories vs in a bin directory.  You really should be writing to /usr/local/dotnet for example and then using symlinks for the binaries from /usr/local/bin/ to your /usr/local/dotnet/bin folder.

/usr/local/share should be for architecture independent stuff.  You are definitely not architecture independent.

nodes.author: grosch
nodes.body: Another reason path_helper is silly.  It assumes IT is the only thing setting a path.  As soon as someone sets their own path in their startup files, and doesn't append to what the system gave them, you lose any benefit to using path_helper.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
I'm aware the Go and Mono installers are exceptions, I'm hoping that because they're similar to .NET Core (Mono in particular), seeing the reasons for those decisions can help us understand what we're dealing with. If there's something nasty being avoided by using `path_helper`, I want to know.

> As soon as someone sets their own path in their startup files, and doesn't append to what the system gave them, you lose any benefit to using path_helper.

I think this is a pretty compelling reason to switch. It (or something else about `path_helper`) probably caused https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/2693, and who knows how much trouble for others.

---

> If you're really going to look at changing your installer, I'd ask you also look into why you're writing to /usr/local/share in the first place and even worse putting a binary at the same level as files and directories vs in a bin directory.

There's no need to batch that feedback up with this issue, IMO. Leading up to 3.0, as long as a change is good I don't think there's a huge amount of momentum to overcome. If you don't mind creating a new issue with some specifics about the dangers with the current layout I think that's a good place to start. (I think Core-Setup is the right place for that discussion too, but I think it'll be a larger one.)

There's info about the current layout at https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/58/files, although I don't see that much info *why* some of the longstanding conventions exist.

nodes.author: tom-seddon
nodes.body:
I had this problem today. Mojave 10.14.6, with zsh as my login shell. zsh just never seems to run `/etc/profile`, so `path_helper` is never called, so `dotnet` doesn't end up on the path.

Catalina has an `/etc/zprofile` that calls `path_helper`, presumably to fix this very issue, so I suspect the tools will straight away work fine on that.

For now, I've added a call to `path_helper` to my `~/.zshenv`: `test -x /usr/libexec/path_helper && eval $(/usr/libexec/path_helper -s)`. Now I can run `dotnet` without any messing about.

(This also magically made the Go tools appear on my path by default. Always annoyed me I'd had to do that manually. Now I know why.)

Thanks,

--Tom

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body: Thanks for the extra info, interesting that this repros for fresh zsh usage, not only broken shell configurations. Still worth getting rid of our dependency on `path_helper` to make things simpler for everybody, IMO. We're looking at doing this for 5.0.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
> We're looking at doing this for 5.0.

Marking this issue untriaged to re-evaluate this--the milestone is currently Future, not 5.0 (or 6.0).

nodes.author: leecow
nodes.body: @NikolaMilosavljevic - is this something you would tackle? Would be great if we could get it into the 6.0 work.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
> @NikolaMilosavljevic - is this something you would tackle? Would be great if we could get it into the 6.0 work.

It seems that there is room for improvement here to support pre-Catalina versions, that don't have path_helper in zsh.

cc @dleeapho

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body: That's true, but just to make sure the other scenarios are still in mind, a "bad" `.bash_profile` can also cause this, or different non-standard shells that don't support `path_helper`.

nodes.author: FyiurAmron
nodes.body:
>a "bad" .bash_profile can also cause this, or different non-standard shells that don't support path_helper.

@dagood ain't that a good enough reason by itself to favour symlinks over `path_helper`?

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
> > a "bad" .bash_profile can also cause this, or different non-standard shells that don't support path_helper.
> 
> ain't that a good enough reason by itself to favour symlinks over `path_helper`?

That comment was only meant as a reminder that I *do* think there's plenty of justification to remove `path_helper`. 😄 Specifically: even though Catalina+ doesn't seem to have this issue in its default state, I still think .NET should remove the dependency on `path_helper` even if support for pre-Catalina OSes is dropped in the future.

This was where I meant to make my opinion clear, in an earlier comment:

> > Still worth getting rid of our dependency on `path_helper` to make things simpler for everybody, IMO.

The only reason I know of that this hasn't been changed yet is that nobody has been able to spend the time to develop the change and validate that it won't break anyone.

nodes.author: dleeapho
nodes.body: cc @NikolaMilosavljevic

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: We should plan a switch away from `path_helper`. I've added `untriaged` label to bring this issue to triage to determine the appropriate timelines for the fix.

nodes.author: weltkante
nodes.body:
>  it appears we get "Misc" string from .NET Runtime

Not really, the .NET Runtime code will look at attributes defined on your classes/properties via reflection or a registered dynamic TypeDescriptorProvider. If the type you are looking at is in your assembly you are still responsible for properly annotating it, even if the data is retrieved through .NET Runtime infrastructure.

From a quick look, the properties in question are missing `[SRCategory(...)]` attributes. If you meant that the _default value_ for properties not annotated otherwise is coming from .NET Runtime and not being localized, that may be true.

So the question is probably whether you want to push .NET Runtime to localize their default value, or if you just want to annotate all designer visible control properties with SRCategory to ensure they are localized.

nodes.author: RussKie
nodes.body:
> your assembly you are still responsible for properly annotating it

Yes, however it may be a stretch to expect _all_ properties on a given object annotated - one can bind an arbitrary object to a property grid.
Without spending too much time and debugging `TypeDescriptor` it is hard to tell where "Misc" string comes from, but it doesn't appear come from us in any shape or form. 

Further .NET Runtime is not being localised at all (no plans for that either), which is likely what brought us here.

nodes.author: weltkante
nodes.body:
> Further .NET Runtime is not being localised at all 

They are localizing exceptions, unless they reverted that decision. It already has been aknowledged that some exceptions are exposed to end users (not just developers) via WinForms and WPF binding and validation systems.

I'd expect this TypeDescriptor situation fall under the same rules, it can end up with the end user if someone places a PropertyGrid in his application, so it should be localized like exception messages.

If it were design-time visible only you could probably argue to override defaults by installing a TypeDescriptorProvider instead of annotating every single property. But for runtime end-user facing behavior its better to fix right at the source since there is literally no situation where you don't want this localized.

nodes.author: RussKie
nodes.body: @nakarnam FYI

nodes.author: elachlan
nodes.body: So is the fix in runtime and not winforms? Should we move it there? It seems more correct to me, since its the default and if a property is missed when annotating, it will still show as `misc`.

nodes.author: elachlan
nodes.body: CC: @dreddy-work / @merriemcgaw can we move this to runtime or should it stay here in winforms?

Verified on latest 8.0 build .NET 8.0.100-alpha.1.23060.24，the "Msic" component is still not localized in the local language OS, but the location has changed.

nodes.author: weltkante
nodes.body:
> So is the fix in runtime and not winforms?

No, I was saying that the runtime is localizing certain things, and so should WinForms. This is declared in WinForms so it should be localized there.

The question is whether hosting a PropertyGrid for WinForms controls to the end user (not the developer) is still a supported scenario. It was in Desktop Framework but a lot of the designer hosting has been moved outside WinForms into a VS component, so I don't believe its currently reasonable to host a control designer to the end user? (It still is possible to build custom designers, but I'm not sure if its intended to be used with the WinForms controls, or just is left around to be used by 3rd party report designers and the like.)

The team has to comment on their plans in that regard, it may be possible to drop this issue if these properties are no longer designable in hosted designers.

nodes.author: elachlan
nodes.body:
> This is declared in WinForms so it should be localized there.

We already have a translation for it:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/a1aa54dff0f6635d3dfb1381aecc0d5d79ed254a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/Resources/xlf/SR.ru.xlf#L8240-L8244

Which is only used in:
https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/a1aa54dff0f6635d3dfb1381aecc0d5d79ed254a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/ComponentModel/COM2Interop/COM2ICategorizePropertiesHandler.cs#L14-L32

BUT, if you look at the Attributes we use `[SRCategory(nameof(SR.CatBehavior))]`. Its using the localization from runtime. As far as I can tell there is no `SR.CatMisc`.

nodes.author: elachlan
nodes.body:
I found this in runtime, I am unsure if it is related.
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/76b5b76ceb08baa587178f8654df1a964547930b/src/libraries/System.ComponentModel.Primitives/src/System/ComponentModel/CategoryAttribute.cs#L199-L226

nodes.author: elachlan
nodes.body:
okay, found it.

So the default constructor of `CategoryAttribute` uses a category value of `Default`. `CategoryAttribute.Category` property calls `GetLocalizedString` which maps `Default` to `SR.PropertyCategoryDefault`. 

`PropertyCategoryDefault` is located in `Strings.resx`:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/76b5b76ceb08baa587178f8654df1a964547930b/src/libraries/System.ComponentModel.Primitives/src/Resources/Strings.resx#L84-L86

Trying to override it in Winforms does not work and runtime doesn't localize those values as far as I can tell (no xlf folder).

So we would have to ask runtime to localize those values.

author: dagood
body:
https://github.com/dotnet/docs/pull/14339#discussion_r323612440

> I had a look in the Microsoft rpms (using `rpm -ql <rpm>` and seeing if the folder shows up). It seems like this is taken care of mostly. I saw to cases where it isn't: No package owns the `packs` folder. Also templates, which are part of the sdk package, only list files. The `templates`, and `templates/<version>` folder don't show up.

Something in Core-Setup should probably own `packs`.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body: We need to figure out if this impacts major scenarios, might not fit 3.1 GA.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
Potential problems caused by this issue are described at https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/packaging-guidelines/UnownedDirectories/, headers:

* Inaccessible Directories
* Directories not Removed [when uninstalling]
* Directories cannot be Verified [with `rpm -V` nor `rpm -qf`]
* ./configure Scripts can Fail

Our targeting pack RPMs are generated using infra that doesn't account for this, I think:

https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/57fa3b22a41db5752d8c85762336a9a22ec235ec/src/pkg/packaging/rpm/dotnet-sharedframework-rpm_config.json#L42-L45

If that's right, [`GetRpmInstallerJsonProperties`](https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/blob/f757dab263c59ffa51717974ec9a5da76a7a3b6e/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Build.Tasks.SharedFramework.Sdk/targets/installer.targets#L145-L152) needs to be improved to add this ownership list.

I believe we should fix in 5.0 and consider as a servicing fix for 3.1.

Installing then uninstalling `dotnet-sdk-3.0` leaves these dirs around (we need to fix this for templates as well, in dotnet/core-sdk):

```
$ find /usr/share/dotnet/
/usr/share/dotnet/
/usr/share/dotnet/templates
/usr/share/dotnet/templates/3.0.0
/usr/share/dotnet/packs
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/NETStandard.Library.Ref
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/NETStandard.Library.Ref/2.1.0
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/NETStandard.Library.Ref/2.1.0/ref
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/NETStandard.Library.Ref/2.1.0/ref/netstandard2.1
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/NETStandard.Library.Ref/2.1.0/data
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/3.0.0
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/3.0.0/runtimes
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/3.0.0/runtimes/linux-x64
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/3.0.0/runtimes/linux-x64/native
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Ref
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Ref/3.0.0
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Ref/3.0.0/ref
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Ref/3.0.0/ref/netcoreapp3.0
/usr/share/dotnet/packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Ref/3.0.0/data
```

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
I found this doc about guidelines that I think is quite useful for `packs` ownership: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/PackagingDrafts/Revised_File_and_Directory_Ownership

When I look at the `packs` dir, what I'm thinking first is if it's reasonable to add a dependency from the targeting packs to something that owns the `packs` dir. The targeting pack RPMs don't currently have any dependencies, and there are no packages in core-setup that I think make sense to own the `packs` dir since it is only relevant for SDK installs.

I think having all packs co-own the directories is the way to go, "[The directory is owned by a package which is not required for your package to function.](https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/PackagingDrafts/Revised_File_and_Directory_Ownership#The_directory_is_owned_by_a_package_which_is_not_required_for_your_package_to_function.)"

A virtual package for the "SDK filesystem" is an alternative, but it would make the set of RPM packages diverge from the set of Debian packages so I don't see it as a great option.

I believe the packs also need to co-own `dotnet`, or else that would still be an unowned directory. (For example, someone may have the .NET Core SDK in `~` but want to use the distro-provided targeting packs. If `dotnet` isn't owned, that dir would stick around after uninstalling the targeting packs.)

title: Fix directory ownership of RPM packages

author: dagood
body:
When adding functionality to skip building targeting packs in servicing builds unless they're being patched (https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/issues/8735), the tests broke because they assumed the targeting packs would always be built.

The short-term fix was to change the tests to simply pass when the nupkg doesn't exist.

master: https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/pull/8824
windowsdesktop master: https://github.com/dotnet/windowsdesktop/pull/230
3.0: https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/pull/8827
3.1: https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/pull/8828

This could cause the tests to pass even when a nupkg should have been created. It's unlikely this will cause problems (details in 3.0/3.1 PRs above) but in any case, it's a regression in testing coverage that should be closed.

The difficulty here is wiring through the info about whether a package should have been created all the way to the test code. A simple approach would be to put a `{nupkgFileName}.intentionallyNotBuilt` file in the artifacts dir when a build is skipped, then the tests look for it based on convention.

nodes.body: [Triage] @jkoritzinsky is this implemented with SharedFX refactoring or would it be valuable to add it?

nodes.author: jkoritzinsky
nodes.body: I think including some sort of check tooling for this might be useful, but it isn't urgent. This was not implemented with the SharedFX refactoring.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: @ericstj does this test make sense now that we are servicing targeting packs with every release?

nodes.author: ericstj

Maybe those tests could be reverted back to the not do this:

> The short-term fix was to change the tests to simply pass when the nupkg doesn't exist.

title: Make targeting pack test fail if nupkg doesn't exist but should've been built

author: dagood
body: Right now, the apphost template file gives execute and write permissions to owner: `-rwxr--r--`. These aren't necessary, `-r--r--r--` would be better. See https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/issues/7062#issuecomment-516936557 and convo in that thread. I believe this should also apply to the Deb/RPM packages.

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body: In my understanding; if we set this permission in toolset: https://github.com/dotnet/toolset/pull/3623, we do not need to make the change anywhere else. Is there any other reason to keep `u+x` permission in toolset?

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body: After taking a look at https://github.com/dotnet/toolset/pull/3623, I think the missing link is the difference between template apphost and generated apphost (apphost shim). The template is put on disk by installers, the tar.gz, or NuGet packages. The apphost template is never executed so it doesn't need `u+x` (or anything else above `r`). It's read by the SDK during `dotnet publish` and some content is replaced to produce a generated apphost (apphost shim) that runs the app. The shim needs `x` so it can be executed.

nodes.author: am11
nodes.body: Is it possible to enforce the permission through .tar.gz? Seems like we can preserve file permission with `-p` in `.tar.gz`, but that is only the creation time fix. On extraction time, we still expect user to use `-p`. For example: https://github.com/dotnet/toolset/blob/3a43b10/scripts/obtain/dotnet-install.sh#L680.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
> Is it possible to enforce the permission through .tar.gz? Seems like we can preserve file permission with `-p` in `.tar.gz`, but that is only the creation time fix.

I don't *think* we need to enforce it to that degree--if someone chooses to extract without preserving permissions, that's up to them, and they can also change permissions afterwards and I don't think we can go after that.

The concern I believe we have is someone installing .NET Core with a Microsoft-supported method and ending up with the template apphost on their disk owned by `root` with more permissions granted than are actually needed. /cc @vitek-karas @swaroop-sridhar 

> For example: https://github.com/dotnet/toolset/blob/3a43b10/scripts/obtain/dotnet-install.sh#L680.

Missing permission-preserving args in `dotnet-install.sh` seems borderline... we expect people to run that as a user, not root, so we may not have the same concern there. I'm not sure. (If we do fix, we have to be very careful it doesn't break some other scenario because of some assumption that no longer holds up.)

nodes.author: omajid
nodes.body:
> These aren't necessary, `-r--r--r--` would be better.

I just realized that `-rx-rx-rx-` might be better, after all.

The native distro tooling that deals with debuginfo stripping (see https://github.com/dotnet/source-build/issues/267) only strips executibles. Making things `-r--r--r--` means that the tooling skips these binaries when it comes to handling debuginfo correctly.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
Maybe a way to frame this is that the apphost template *isn't* executable, at least by the definition of "does something useful when executed"... it's only useful once the SDK makes the apphost shim using the template. It might make more sense to strip the symbols when the dev actually publishes their .NET Core app as a RPM/Deb package?

Something to consider is if the symbols on the apphost template "match" the bits on the generated apphost shim. (E.g. does the binary replacement cause some offsets to stop working?) If not, then stripping is the wrong thing to do either way, since the generated shims will not be debuggable at all. If that's not a problem, I suppose this discussion is about pragmatics:

* Template file size (in the apphost pack that everyone installs)
* Whether we're exposing security surface area by installing this template as `x` when it doesn't need it
* Whether we should go along with distro packaging tools' expectations (defaults?) to get an end result we want even though the conventions don't quite seem accurate vs. what these files truly are

I think we need more info from the host folks (@vitek-karas, @swaroop-sridhar, ...?) to know how to properly weigh this or get a firm requirement.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
We do need the host to be debuggable - not due to actual devs debugging it (although that also helps), but due to dump collection and analysis. If there are no symbols the automatic analysis gets thrown off and reports weird results.
Did we measure how much we save by stripping symbols?

I assume this only applies to Linux/Mac since on Windows the symbols are in a separate file.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
To be concrete, my question is: can the *generated apphost shim* be debugged using symbols that were stripped from the *apphost template*? It sounds like yes, and we're already depending on that.

My suggestion above is exploring the idea that this assumption might not make sense, in particular in source-build. Maybe it's odd to think about it this way, but it seems like when the SDK replaces content in the apphost template, it's producing an executable file that "belongs" to the developer, so they might expect to own its symbols as well.

Maybe the replacements the SDK makes are small enough that we should think of this scenario as the dev redistributing a file that's *largely* unchanged.

---

@omajid is it possible to strip symbols manually when the file isn't detected by the packaging tooling? I'm sure it's not recommended--but at the root of all this, I believe we want to avoid `x` as a security measure.

> Did we measure how much we save by stripping symbols?

I wouldn't expect anyone to already have this measurement, since in the Microsoft build we strip symbols as a matter of course.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
I think the amount of modifications done by the SDK is small enough that the binary is still in spirit produces by Microsoft. It's kind of split:
* For purposes of ownership, servicing and security (signing and such) the modified binary produced by SDK is owned by the app developer.
* For purposes of diagnostics, crash dumps and so on - Microsoft authored all the code in it, so we own that. Not counting the fact that we currently don't have the tools necessary to produce a workable `.pdb` inside the SDK itself - so from a practical point of view, the symbols must be produced by the official build.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
Ok, so I think we've arrived at a baseline: we don't believe the SDK can reasonably generate a debuggable apphost shim (whether that be generating a PDB, replacing content in a way that doesn't interfere with `.so` or `.dylib` symbols, etc.). The only place we think that can happen is when building the template.

That still leaves the dilemma from @omajid... install the apphost template as `-r--r--r--` for security and correctness like this issue tracks, or set it to `-rx-rx-rx-` so that source-build can (more easily?) produce a debuginfo package using normal RPM tooling?

---

> * For purposes of diagnostics, crash dumps and so on - Microsoft authored all the code in it, so we own that.

A little nitpicking here--there are non-Microsoft contributors, and Microsoft isn't the only org building, delivering, and potentially needing to debug .NET Core. Ideally we can choose something here that will also work for source-build.

nodes.author: vitek-karas
nodes.body:
You're absolutely right - I simply wanted to say that whoever builds the "repo" sources is the "owner" of the debugging experience.

One more small correction - the SDK does today produce a debuggable apphost. The way it does that is that it takes the debuggable template produced by "repo build" and modifies it. The modifications are small enough that they don't "break" the debuggability.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] @NikolaMilosavljevic can you check if this repros?

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
This still repros and shows slightly different permissions:

```
[root@92d1b9cf52f9 dotnet]# ls -l ./sdk/6.0.400/AppHostTemplate/apphost ./packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/6.0.8/runtimes/linux-x64/native/apphost
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 142840 Jul 13 18:10 ./packs/Microsoft.NETCore.App.Host.linux-x64/6.0.8/runtimes/linux-x64/native/apphost
-rwxr--r-- 1 root root 142840 Jul 21 18:33 ./sdk/6.0.400/AppHostTemplate/apphost
```

As the fix is likely needed in a different repo, making change for 7.0.0 is highly unlikely - moving to 8.0.0.

title: Reduce apphost template permissions in SDK tar.gz

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
.NET Host MSI installs components shared across releases, to a shared location, using static component codes.

This issue tracks defining valid experiences and desired outcomes and will serve as a source for new issues, fixes or features in the product.

While components are shared across releases, and properly ref-counted, MSIs in different .NET (Core) releases are different (distinct) and do not upgrade one another.

This design is blocking some scenarios, i.e. renaming any of the files carried by these components, see https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/2243. Renaming the file without doing more changes in .NET Core 3.1 and .NET 5.0 would result in 2 files installed next to each other, old (ThirdPartNotices.txt) and new (THIRD-PARTY-NOTICES.txt). Further analysis of 3.1 and 5.0 installers is required to solve that problem.

Some of the open questions:
1) Should .NET Host MSI have the static upgrade code?
2) Should new versions of .NET Host MSI upgrade products shipped with previous releases?

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: @dleeapho @dagood @leecow @MichaelSimons @nakarnam

nodes.author: leecow
nodes.body: Make sure to include the Host folks (Vitek and others) in any design discussions.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] we should investigate using static upgrade code.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] @ashnaga can we add this to any current epics for Windows installation improvements?

title: .NET Host MSI's upgrade during one major release and across several releases

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
Source-built .NET is in Fedora and CentOS. There are numerous reports of people hitting issues when some packages on their machines come from the Microsoft repos and others from the distro archive. These packages don't work well together, i.e. they don't mix well. They have different dotnet roots, /usr/share/dotnet vs. /usr/lib64/dotnet. Here's one recent report: https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/issues/15476

Additionally, packages from different distro repositories, i.e. Fedora and RHEL could cause similar issues. Packages are never meant to be mixed, only a single repository should ever be used.

We need to find a way to help customers avoid this issue. Better documentation could help, but is not the preferred or only solution. Other packages and application vendors could have found themselves in the same situation. We need to find ways to leverage distro and community knowledge to come up with a proper mitigation.

nodes.author: hoyosjs
nodes.body: cc: @omajid @tmds

nodes.author: wfurt
nodes.body: It seems like `DOTNET_MULTILEVEL_LOOKUP=0` as meant for that e.g. restrict dotnet to be "smart" and look outside of given location.

Failed:

```

Can we move this issue to source-build repo?

cc @dagood

nodes.author: omajid
nodes.body:
Yum repository files have a `priority` option that lets `dnf`/`yum` modify how important a repository is treated. We can adjust it to make `dnf`/`yum` prefer packages from other repositories. 

The default repo priority is 99, and if a repo *increases* the value of the `priority`,  it is *less* prioritized for fetching packages. (Yes, this seems a bit counter-intuitive that smaller priority numbers actually mean a higher priority).

Here's a test on Fedora 33:

```
$ sudo dnf remove '*dotnet*'                                                                                                            
No match for argument: *dotnet*                                                                                                                               
No packages marked for removal.                                                                                                                               
Dependencies resolved.
Nothing to do.                                                                                                                                                
Complete!               
$ rpm -qa | grep dotnet

$ wget https://packages.microsoft.com/config/fedora/33/prod.repo 
$ sudo cp prod.repo /etc/yum.repos.d/microsoft.repo
$ sudo dnf install dotnet-sdk-3.1                                     
packages-microsoft-com-prod                                                                                                   279 kB/s | 182 kB     00:00    
Dependencies resolved.                                                                                                                                        
========================================================================================================
 Package                          Architecture   Version           Repository                      Size
========================================================================================================
Installing:                                                                                             
 dotnet-sdk-3.1                   x86_64         3.1.405-1         packages-microsoft-com-prod     71 M
Installing dependencies:                                                                                
 aspnetcore-runtime-3.1           x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                        6.2 M
 aspnetcore-targeting-pack-3.1    x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                        1.0 M
 dotnet-apphost-pack-3.1          x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                         71 k
 dotnet-host                      x86_64         5.0.2-1           packages-microsoft-com-prod     64 k
 dotnet-hostfxr-3.1               x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                        166 k
 dotnet-runtime-3.1               x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                         27 M
 dotnet-targeting-pack-3.1        x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33     updates                        1.8 M
 netstandard-targeting-pack-2.1   x86_64         3.1.111-1.fc33    updates                        1.3 M
                                                                                                        
Transaction Summary                                                                                     
========================================================================================================
Install  9 Packages                                                                                                                                           

Total download size: 108 M
Installed size: 344 M                                                                                                                                         
Is this ok [y/N]: n 
Operation aborted.

# Reduce the priority of the Microsoft repository
$ sudo dnf config-manager --save --setopt="*microsoft-*.priority=100"

$ sudo dnf install dotnet-sdk-3.1                         
Dependencies resolved.
==========================================================================================
 Package                          Architecture   Version            Repository       Size
==========================================================================================
Installing:
 dotnet-sdk-3.1                   x86_64         3.1.111-1.fc33     updates          40 M
Installing dependencies:
 aspnetcore-runtime-3.1           x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates         6.2 M
 aspnetcore-targeting-pack-3.1    x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates         1.0 M
 dotnet-apphost-pack-3.1          x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates          71 k
 dotnet-host                      x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates         105 k
 dotnet-hostfxr-3.1               x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates         166 k
 dotnet-runtime-3.1               x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates          27 M
 dotnet-targeting-pack-3.1        x86_64         3.1.11-1.fc33      updates         1.8 M
 dotnet-templates-3.1             x86_64         3.1.111-1.fc33     updates         1.8 M
 netstandard-targeting-pack-2.1   x86_64         3.1.111-1.fc33     updates         1.3 M

Transaction Summary
==========================================================================================
Install  10 Packages

Total download size: 80 M
Installed size: 300 M
Is this ok [y/N]: n

```

If we can insert this option directly in the repo file, that might be good enough. We can do this by adding this line directly in the repo file: `priority=100`. Otherwise, we can ask users to run `sudo dnf config-manager --save --setopt="*microsoft-*.priority=100"`. The command is slightly different with `yum` and I haven't tested it.

nodes.author: omajid
nodes.body: The proposed `priority=100` option wont help in the case where the user wants to install `dotnet-sdk-5.0` (not available in Fedora repos yet) with `dotnet-sdk-3.1` (available in Fedora repos). That would still break with repo prioritization because `dotnet-sdk-5.0` will be fetched from the MIcrosoft repo and placed at `/usr/share/dotnet`, while the host will probably try and use `/usr/lib64/dotnet` instead.

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
Oh wow, when I saw priority mentioned in one of these issues earlier (I've been collecting the ones I see in https://github.com/dotnet/docs/issues/18347), based on the name, I thought it would only affect what happens when the same package *with the same version* is available in two repos. I'm surprised that it actually prevents upgrade even when a newer version is available on the less prioritized feed. It certainly makes sense that it works this way though, or it would be a pretty weak feature. 😛 

Yeah, to give a little extra context why it doesn't help with 5.0: the mix of packages with major.minor in the name (`dotnet-sdk-5.0`) and no version in the name (`dotnet-host`) means that if you try to get `dotnet-sdk-5.0` from a fresh setup, you'll end up with Microsoft's `dotnet-sdk-5.0` and Fedora's `dotnet-host`, and `dotnet` commands will still fail: you end up with a partial install of 3.1 from Fedora and partial install of 5.0 from Microsoft.

(On the other side, if you *want* to get .NET from packages.microsoft.com, it seems that prioritizing packages.microsoft.com would work, because it's always a superset as far as .NET packages are concerned.)

If we could have fake temporary `dotnet-*-5.0` packages in Fedora that actually just print a warning or something, that seems like it would at least make sure every single package is coming from the one repo with higher priority, preventing the current hostfxr errors that don't really point people at a solution. But I have no idea if that's a reasonable thing to do. Thoughts?

---

> I needed to run a powershell script so I installed powershell using instructions from: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/install/installing-powershell-core-on-linux?view=powershell-7.1#fedora.

This means to me that we have to have packages.microsoft.com themselves actually put the deprioritization in the central repo config files, because the powershell instructions (and more?) just download and install that packages.microsoft.com repo file.

> Can we move this issue to source-build repo?

It certainly affects the use of distros with source-built SDKs. (/cc @dseefeld @crummel.) But I'm not sure what we can do about this on the source-build side--dotnet/runtime area-Setup is about the Microsoft packaging side of things, so I think it's correct to be here.

nodes.author: omajid
nodes.body:
> If we could have fake temporary dotnet-*-5.0 packages in Fedora that actually just print a warning or something, that seems like it would at least make sure every single package is coming from the one repo with higher priority, preventing the current hostfxr errors that don't really point people at a solution. But I have no idea if that's a reasonable thing to do. Thoughts?

For .NET 5.0, at least, I think it would be faster to just review and build the real packages. They are ready from my side and I am waiting for a formal review: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1919037

It looks like this problem also shows up for feature bands that Fedora doesn't build--I suppose priority doesn't block an install that includes the exact version. Installing `dotnet-sdk-3.1` or `dotnet-sdk-3.1-3.1.111` pulls from Fedora, but `dotnet-sdk-3.1.405` still pulls from Microsoft.

# dnf install dotnet-sdk-3.1-3.1.405

Installing dependencies:

(The result is that `dotnet` finds no SDKs because they're off in some unknown location.)

nodes.author: tmds
nodes.body:
The proposed solution is to lower the priority on the repo files from Microsoft in order to give preference to the dotnet packages that come with the distro.

With this known issue: in case a .NET version is not yet available from distro packages, pulling that version from the Microsoft repo will cause some/all versions not to work.

Can the priority can be added into the repo file at https://packages.microsoft.com/config/rhel/7/prod.repo?
Are there expected issues from including it?

nodes.author: dagood
nodes.body:
> Can the priority can be added into the repo file at https://packages.microsoft.com/config/rhel/7/prod.repo?

It certainly helps the install experience. My understanding is this is waiting for review from the `area-Setup` folks before asking the packages.microsoft.com team to do these changes.

A few more things to think about:

* How does this affect the upgrade experience for those who already have .NET installed from packages.microsoft.com with the current priority?
  * Lowest release band, 3.1.111, available in the distro?
  * Higher release band, 3.1.405, not available in the distro?
* What if we prioritize packages.microsoft.com instead?
  * I hope we don't have to, but it seems worth evaluating even if just to document how it leaves everyone worse off.
* Does all of this behave the same for Debian-based distros? (Future: Alpine?)

---

More generally, I want to point out that nothing proposed so far seems to fix all problems--we still need documentation to help people fix up their installs and get the bits installed that they actually want. I think holding off on https://github.com/dotnet/docs/issues/18347 is not good.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] We need to break this into specific scenarios and prioritize them. Please consider Previews and future distro support.

nodes.author: dleeapho
nodes.body: /cc @rconard

nodes.author: MichaelSimons
nodes.body:
>Does all of this behave the same for Debian-based distros?

FWIW, I found this [answer on askubuntu](https://askubuntu.com/a/153408) to be a helpful read on this topic.  The short answer is similar mechanism exist to control which package source is used/prioritized but may have the same potential issue of not having a single solution for all scenarios.  Furthermore these settings are at the machine level, not the feed level.

title: Is there a .NET Runtime package for Windows Store?

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
## Situation

Customers rely on timely and constant availability of .NET's RPM and DEB packages on packages.microsoft.com.

Any disruption in access, delay in delivery or issues with content, creates unmeasurable impact to our customers.

Examples of issues we've seen in the past:
1) some mirrors had stale or incomplete packages,
2) stale index,
3) partial release and missing dependencies.
4) SxS install of .NET preview releases, alongside repo-built packages, see: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/47500

## Objective

Ensure we have testable processes in place for all stages of the release, and tests are executed with each release and package updates.

Ensure that all mirrors are consistent and there is an easy way of validating this.

Ensure that .NET package set, on packages.microsoft.com, is complete, for all supported platforms.

## Execution

Using following metrics, determine areas for improvements, create proposals and prototypes and schedule implementations.

Metrics:
- package availability on packages.microsoft.com and all mirrors
- validations of expected user scenarios - before or after packages are live
- guidance - SxS and previews and any known issues
- feedback - customers have a way to provide actionable feedback to each stage and process owner
- end-to-end process tracking

nodes.body: I couldn't figure out the best area label to add to this issue. If you have write-permissions please help me learn by adding exactly one [area label](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/area-owners.md).

nodes.author: MichaelSimons
nodes.body:
One suggestion to investigate is mentioned [here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/linux-package-mixup) which describes how YUM supports excludes when registering a feed

```
echo 'excludepkgs=dotnet*,aspnet*,netstandard*' | sudo tee -a /etc/yum.repos.d/microsoft-prod.repo
sudo dnf remove 'dotnet*' 'aspnet*' 'netstandard*'
sudo dnf install dotnet-sdk-5.0
```

nodes.author: MNLierman
nodes.body:
Hi, I know this is an old issue, but I would like to mention that on our systems, there are a few vendor apps we're testing, compiled using .Net 5 x86 only, originally for a client's specific industry in which they were being sold 32-bit only tablets. When installing the x86 .NET Redistributable, we've ran into exactly what you've said, that installing both .NET Redistributables could causes issues. Three SxS errors are logged in Event Viewer at random intervals between every 10 minutes to every 2 hours, even though the application was only opened a couple of times and is not open when the errors are logged. Not sure if this is by design.

`“Activation context generation failed for "C:\Application Path\application.exe". Error in manifest or policy file "" on line . A component version required by the application conflicts with another component version already active. Conflicting components are:. Component 1: C:\WINDOWS\WinSxS\manifests\x86_microsoft.windows.common-controls_(snip)manifest. Component 2: C:\WINDOWS\WinSxS\manifests\amd64_microsoft.windows.common-controls_(snip).manifest.”`

**According to this issue, the solution:** Uninstall the conflicting 32-bit x86 .NET Redistributable unless you absolutely have to have it. Find the 64-bit version of the application or install VirtualBox/Hyper-V and run old applications there. 

I'm making the decision to install Hyper-V on a couple of the tech workstations at the office which automatically and seamlessly configures the system as a Type 1 Hypervisor, and all other VMs are then also Type 1s with direct access. VirtualBox without Hyper-V could also be used, but Type 1 VMs provide significant performance benefits. VirtualBox can be configured to use the Hyper-V hypervisor, however, which may be a more comfortable UI for some.

Hope this helps someone else. Surprised this isn't documented anywhere else.

title: Documentation unclear on whether the x64 installer of the .NET runtime also installs the 32-bit runtime

author: HylianSteel
body:
### Description

I propose that the .net core runtimes set their DisplayIcon registry entry to use C:\Windows\system32\msiexec.exe,0 like the Visual C++ runtimes do. Currently, they use the icon from their individual installer instead. In Windows 10 you can't tell the difference visually. But in Windows 11, which uses an updated Icon, the icon is out of place. This can be seen on all currently supported versions of .net Core (3.1, 5, 6).

### Reproduction Steps

install any currently supported .net core runtime and check Control Panel or Settings ->Apps -> Apps & features to see the incorrect icon being used.

### Expected behavior

The icons shown in Control Panel and Settings ->Apps -> Apps & features for each .net core runtime should be using the icon included in C:\Windows\system32\msiexec.exe like the Visual C++ Redistributables do as it is more uniform that way and it will then rely on icons that are included with the respective Windows version that .net core runtimes will be installed on.

### Actual behavior

The icons shown in Control Panel and Settings ->Apps -> Apps & features for each .net core runtime is using the icon from their respective installers instead of using the right icon included in windows, which is the icon included in C:\Windows\system32\msiexec.exe.

### Regression?

_No response_

### Known Workarounds

a savvy registry user can locate the registry keys in Computer\HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\WOW6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall and change DisplayIcon to C:\Windows\system32\msiexec.exe,0 for each entry as they like. This would have to be repeated for every update to .net core runtimes though.

### Configuration

Version of .net core runtimes: all supported versions (3.1, 5, 6)
Installed OS Version: Windows 11 x64 21H2 22000.258
This is not specific to the above listed configuration

### Other information

_No response_

author: ericstj
body:
Download 2 copies of .NET sdk for Mac.
EG:
https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/thank-you/sdk-5.0.100-macos-x64-installer
https://dotnet.microsoft.com/download/dotnet/thank-you/sdk-5.0.401-macos-x64-installer

Install newer one first, checking the version of dotnet
```
sudo installer -dumplog -target / -pkg ~/Downloads/dotnet-sdk-5.0.401-osx-x64.pkg
strings /usr/local/share/dotnet/dotnet  | grep "@(#)"                                            
@(#)Version 5.0.1021.41214 @Commit: e1825b4928afa9455cc51e1de2b2e66c8be3018d
```

Install older one, checking the version of dotnet
```
sudo installer -dumplog -target / -pkg ~/Downloads/dotnet-sdk-5.0.100-osx-x64.pkg
strings /usr/local/share/dotnet/dotnet  | grep "@(#)"                                            
@(#)Version 5.0.20.51904 @Commit: cf258a14b70ad9069470a108f13765e0e5988f51
```

Note that the older installer installed the old host, despite a newer one being present.

If I had to guess, I would have expected that `IncludeVersionInMacOSComponentName`  was meant to try to avoid this.

I do see this set by the host package:
https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/83024a1bf2948c4e4124983e52b8c3d2b56c32ce/src/installer/pkg/sfx/installers/dotnet-host.proj#L18

If I decompress the bundles, I see that the host's package id is indeed version-less:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<pkg-info overwrite-permissions="true" relocatable="false" identifier="com.microsoft.dotnet.sharedhost.component.osx.x64" postinstall-action="none" version="5.0.10" format-version="2" generator-version="InstallCmds-681 (18G9323)" install-location="/usr/local/share/dotnet" auth="root">
    <payload numberOfFiles="4" installKBytes="183"/>
    <bundle-version/>
    <upgrade-bundle/>
    <update-bundle/>
    <atomic-update-bundle/>
    <strict-identifier/>
    <relocate/>
    <scripts>
        <postinstall file="./postinstall"/>
    </scripts>
</pkg-info>
```

I wonder if we're missing something to make it so that this package does not try to overwrite a lower version?

If I had to guess, I would have expected that `IncludeVersionInMacOSComponentName` was meant to try to avoid this. I do see this set by the host package: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/83024a1bf2948c4e4124983e52b8c3d2b56c32ce/src/installer/pkg/sfx/installers/dotnet-host.proj#L18 If I decompress the bundles, I see that the host's package id is indeed version-less: ```xml ``` I wonder if we're missing something to make it so that this package does not try to overwrite a lower version?

title: Installing an old version of shared host on mac will overwrite a newer version

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
It appears that Microsoft-built .NET installers, provided on https://packages.microsoft.com, are not creating `/etc/dotnet/install_location` file on Linux systems. The file gets created on OSX.

This causes issues for customers that want to customize the install location due to 1) missing file, and 2) default permissions for new file, created by customer.

.NET installer should create this file, according to design document: https://github.com/dotnet/designs/blob/main/accepted/2020/install-locations.md

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: This should be backported to all supported releases.

nodes.author: richlander
nodes.body: This is technically a breaking change, so we should document that.

nodes.author: richlander
nodes.body:
What Ubuntu looks like:

```bash
$ docker run --rm -it  ubuntu:jammy
root@4da5efec1e6f:/# apt update && apt install -y dotnet6
root@4da5efec1e6f:/# ls /etc/dotnet
install_location  install_location_x64
root@4da5efec1e6f:/# cat /etc/dotnet/install_location
/usr/lib/dotnet
root@4da5efec1e6f:/# export | grep DOTNET
root@4da5efec1e6f:/#
```

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
> What Ubuntu looks like:
> 
> ```shell
> $ docker run --rm -it  ubuntu:jammy
> root@4da5efec1e6f:/# apt update && apt install -y dotnet6
> root@4da5efec1e6f:/# ls /etc/dotnet
> install_location  install_location_x64
> root@4da5efec1e6f:/# cat /etc/dotnet/install_location
> /usr/lib/dotnet
> root@4da5efec1e6f:/# export | grep DOTNET
> root@4da5efec1e6f:/#
> ```

DEB packages built by Ubuntu and provided in Ubuntu feeds *do* have `/etc/dotnet/install_location` file. Packages built by Microsoft and provided on https://packages.microsoft.com do not. I've clarified the issue description.

nodes.author: richlander
nodes.body:
Exactly. That is what I meant, but didn't say. Thanks for clarifying.

Does our guidance cover this case?

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
Our packaging guidance (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/distribution-packaging) has a section about this file:

_(16) /etc/dotnet/install_location is a file that contains the full path for {dotnet_root}. The path may end with a newline. It's not necessary to add this file when the root is /usr/share/dotnet._

However, it does not require it, if .NET root is `/usr/share/dotnet`, which is considered a fallback location by the design doc:

_Linux - the host searches in /usr/share/dotnet as a fallback, but the installer may pick a different default based on the requirements of the specific distro/configuration. In such case the install is effectively just like the global install to custom location described below. If correctly registered the host will search the custom location first._

The fix for this issue is likely not needed.

nodes.author: mcallaghan-geotab
nodes.body:
If a system has migrated from Ubuntu distro package installation for dotnet, we found that `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` were still set to `/usr/lib/dotnet` ; but after using the Microsoft distribution package PMC ... this is now wrong because the installation directory should be `/usr/share/dotnet`.

A fix is required.

EDIT: NOTE: Not sure entirely what all will depend on this, but we found Rider IDE relies on it and thus doesn't function properly in this scenario/state.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
> If a system has migrated from Ubuntu distro package installation for dotnet, we found that `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` were still set to `/usr/lib/dotnet` ; but after using the Microsoft distribution package PMC ... this is now wrong because the installation directory should be `/usr/share/dotnet`.
> 
> A fix is required.

This sounds like a "Mixed state scenario 2" from our Ubuntu guidance document: https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/7699. Switching from Ubuntu to Microsoft-built packages require complete uninstall of .NET related packages before installing packages from https://packages.microsoft.com. Uninstall would correctly remove `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` file(s).

> > A fix is required.
> 
> This sounds like a "Mixed state scenario 2" from our Ubuntu guidance document: [dotnet/core#7699](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/7699). Switching from Ubuntu to Microsoft-built packages require complete uninstall of .NET related packages before installing packages from https://packages.microsoft.com. Uninstall would correctly remove `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` file(s).

did `apt remove dotnet* aspnet* netstandard*` - and re-installed .NET6 & .NET7 from PMC - `install_location` is wrong after that (x)

nodes.author: mcallaghan-geotab
nodes.body:
is the recommendation to REMOVE these files, or ensure they point to `/usr/share/dotnet` when using Microsoft PMC?

either way the Microsoft package installers should probably be checking the system against whatever the requirement is

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
> > > If a system has migrated from Ubuntu distro package installation for dotnet, we found that `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` were still set to `/usr/lib/dotnet` ; but after using the Microsoft distribution package PMC ... this is now wrong because the installation directory should be `/usr/share/dotnet`.
> > > A fix is required.
> > 
> > 
> > This sounds like a "Mixed state scenario 2" from our Ubuntu guidance document: [dotnet/core#7699](https://github.com/dotnet/core/issues/7699). Switching from Ubuntu to Microsoft-built packages require complete uninstall of .NET related packages before installing packages from https://packages.microsoft.com. Uninstall would correctly remove `/etc/dotnet/install_location(_x64)` file(s).
> 
> did `apt remove dotnet* aspnet* netstandard*` - and re-installed .NET6 & .NET7 from PMC - `install_location` is wrong after that (x)

Thanks. I see the same issue on 22.04. It seems that Ubuntu-built .NET packages are not cleaning these files from the machine. This seems by design, as plain `apt remove` command does not remove configuration files, i.e. anything under `/etc`. To remove those, you'd run the command with `--purge` switch, i.e. `apt remove --purge dotnet* aspnet* netstandard*`. I'll update the guidance document.

nodes.author: mcallaghan-geotab
nodes.body: Beyond updating the guidance doc tho; Shouldn't the PMC packages also verify this state? (otherwise users will forever be plagued by this problem and likely we'll be spurring more github issue submissions in the future ...)

nodes.author: mcallaghan-geotab
nodes.body: Maybe also consider: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/tools/dotnet-environment-variables#dotnet_root-dotnet_rootx86 (default location varies now on Linux)

nodes.author: mcallaghan-geotab
nodes.body:
Also just found this ... _finally_ figured out what was setting `DOTNET_ROOT` to the old path

```
$ grep DOTNET_ROOT /etc/profile.d/dotnet*
/etc/profile.d/dotnet.sh:export DOTNET_ROOT=/usr/lib/dotnet
```

EDIT: there is also some dotnet tool ENV var items in there ... here's a snip of the script that is left on a Ubuntu 22.04 system (after having installed the packages from Ubuntu package source)
``` shell
$ cat /etc/profile.d/dotnet.sh

# Set location for AppHost lookup
export DOTNET_ROOT=/usr/lib/dotnet

# Add dotnet tools directory to PATH
DOTNET_TOOLS_PATH="$HOME/.dotnet/tools"
case "$PATH" in
    *"$DOTNET_TOOLS_PATH"* ) true ;;
    * ) PATH="$PATH:$DOTNET_TOOLS_PATH" ;;
esac

# Extract self-contained executables under HOME
# to avoid multi-user issues from using the default '/var/tmp'.
[ -z "$DOTNET_BUNDLE_EXTRACT_BASE_DIR" ] && export DOTNET_BUNDLE_EXTRACT_BASE_DIR="${XDG_CACHE_HOME:-"$HOME"/.cache}/dotnet_bundle_extract"
```

title: Linux installers are not creating /etc/dotnet/install_location file

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
FIPS verification is failing for .NET packages. Creating the issue in `runtime` repo, for tracking - however `aspnetcore` and `installer` repos are also affected.

This seems to be related to MD5 digest which is used by default by `fpm` tooling. See the following similar issue in another RPM package: https://github.com/influxdata/telegraf/issues/10270#issuecomment-993871788 and the fix: https://github.com/influxdata/telegraf/pull/10272

nodes.author: vcsjones
nodes.body:
When you FIPS enable a distro, OpenSSL blocks MD5 from being used, and that bubbles up to dnf trying to install the package.

Somewhere around here I think we need to pass `--rpm-digest sha256` when invoking fpm.

https://github.com/dotnet/installer/blob/96a14748f6591a22d22536eef7eb6e26f154baa7/src/redist/targets/GenerateRPMs.targets#L185-L186

@tmds does that sounds like a sensible thing?

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body:
This also affects packages produced in `runtime` and `aspnetcore` repos. `installer` repo produces .NET SDK package only.

I prefer to keep it here or move to `dotnet/arcade`, as `runtime` packaging uses `arcade` infra, specifically this is the place where we'd add the new parameter: https://github.com/dotnet/arcade/blob/3faeb9817f465151aa4bbcdb315f0a6170206760/src/Microsoft.DotNet.Build.Tasks.Installers/src/BuildFPMToolPreReqs.cs#L214

> @omajid can you answer https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/95759#issuecomment-1846061809?

No. I am not familiar with the fpm tool used by .NET. The normal `rpmbuild` command on every distro (meant to produce packages for that distro only) uses the distro's hash configuration which should already correctly with FIPS. Otherwise FIPS would be entirely unsupported by that distro.

title: .NET RPM packages are failing FIPS verification

author: NikolaMilosavljevic
body:
Related to https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/95759

We've fixed .NET 9 packages and backported changes to .NET 8 and 6. However, `dotnet-sdk` package depends on 2.1.0 version of the targeting pack which is not FIPS compliant.

Dependency:
```
netstandard-targeting-pack-2.1 >= 2.1.0
```

This blocks the regular installation of `dotnet-sdk` on FIPS enabled systems.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] Please investigate and fix.

title: `netstandard-targeting-pack-2.1.0-x64.rpm` cannot be installed on FIPS-enabled system

nodes.author: dviererbe
nodes.body:
Thank you for reporting this issue :)

It looks like that you are running into a migration issue from Microsoft to Canonical built .NET deb packages. One indication of this is that:
1. we (Canonical) do not build a binary package with the name `dotnet-runtime-deps-8.0` and
2. the version numbers you are upgrading from do not contain an `ubuntu…` suffix.

Unfortunately the Microsoft and Canonical built packages are incompatible and can result in the errors reported here. Because of this reason Microsoft gradually started to no longer built packages for platforms that provide their own packages.

To prevent such migration issues you have to do one of the following things:
1. Remove the MS package feed
2. Configure apt to not install dotnet packages from the MS package feed (if you depend on other packages from the MS package feed)
3. Configure apt to not install dotnet packages from the Ubuntu package feed (if you prefer the dotnet packages from the MS package feed)

See the documentation for additional context and detailed instructions how to do that: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/linux-package-mixup?pivots=os-linux-ubuntu#whats-going-on

Let me know if this advice helps!

nodes.author: gwr
nodes.body:
Sorry if this is off topic, but are the build instructions for Ubuntu 22.04 up to date?
The build apparently wants sdk 10 and I don't see any easy way to get that.
What setup are developers using on Ubuntu these days?  Thanks!

nodes.author: dviererbe
nodes.body:
@gwr 

If you want to install .NET 10 on Ubuntu 22.04 and higher¹ you can use official builds from the [.NET previews PPA](https://documentation.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-for-developers/reference/availability/dotnet/#previews-ppa) like this:
```
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:dotnet/previews
sudo apt install dotnet10
```
> [!IMPORTANT]
> Do not install the `dotnet9` and `dotnet10` package on the same system. There is a known conflict that arises when apt tries to install both: https://github.com/dotnet/source-build/issues/5049

> The build apparently wants sdk 10 and I don't see any easy way to get that.

If you want to build .NET 10 from source you require a .NET 10 SDK. .NET depends on .NET and there is no way to get around this. You can either download a pre-built from Microsoft or use our built via the method shown above.

_¹ except for Ubuntu 22.10, because it goes EoL before the .NET 10 release_

author: juergen001
body:
There have been many issues logged over the years (i.e. see https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/issues/60144 and all the linked issues). Some of those issues are very old and not titled in a way that would draw attention to them, for example, referring to .NET 5 when the issue affects .NET 8 also (and presumably .NET 9, I'm guessing).

The summary is: If  Windows Update updates the .NET shared framework, then running .NET applications and services may crash in unpredictable ways sometime afterwards. That means, for example, .NET Windows Services deployed on Windows Server COULD RANDOMLY FAIL at an unrelated time after the update.

Maybe there needs to be some coordination between Windows Updater and the .NET installer?

Or at least an officially recommended workaround, like the one posted on the linked issue?

Can this be given a higher priority?

author: cz-dev-ge
body:
### Description

Similar to #82518, but not quite the same. With .NET 6.0.29 the version of `vcruntime140_cor3.dll` has been raised to `14.38.33135.0`. The same DLL in .NET 8.0.4 however is still on version `14.38.33130.0`. If upgrading a self-contained app from a MSI to an application that uses .NET 8 I get errors in the Microsoft Installer installation.


### Reproduction Steps

1. Create a new application (e.g. dotnet new console -f net6.0)
1. Create a global.json (e.g. dotnet new globaljson --sdk-version 6.0.<newest>)
1. Publish the app as self-contained application (e.g. dotnet publish -c Release --self-contained true -r win-x64)
1. Bundle the application as MSI file (e.g. use WiX toolset or skip this step for now)
1. Repeat steps 1 to 4 for .NET 8.0 (-f net8.0 and --sdk-version 8.0.<newest>)

### Expected behavior

The latest DLLs for .NET self contained builds will be deployed when installing using MSI if there is a previous installation using .NET 6.

### Actual behavior

A downgrade is detected and the installation fails.

### Regression?

See #82518 and #62218.

### Known Workarounds

Use companions in Windows Installer / WiX toolset.

author: jkoritzinsky
body:
Today, we ship the nethost shared and static libraries as part of the host pack. However, we do not ship them (or create symlinks to them from) standard library install locations. As a result, referencing an installed nethost on a machine is extremely difficult. In vcxproj scenarios, nethost can be consumed by a NuGet package reference, but from CMake, there's no good solution. Given that the consumers of nethost are primarily native developers, having a native development-focused discovery story is important.

For Unix-based platforms, we should update our installers to install the nethost in the standard location, so linking to nethost via `-lnethost` works seamlessly.

Alternatively, we should ship a CMake config module for nethost that will be discoverable by CMake's config-style package discovery on all of our target systems, enabling CMake projects to reference nethost with `find_package(nethost)` and `target_link_libraries` seamlessly.

nodes.author: NikolaMilosavljevic
nodes.body: [Triage] We are not considering new features in our installers for 9.0. @jkoritzinsky are there customer asks for this feature?
